subject: RE: [junit] fundamental questions on JUnit
msgSnippet: Tests are merely clients of code, just like any other part of your system. In fact, your unit tests cover all supported uses of your code (over time). If your
messageBody:
Tests are merely clients of code, just like any other part of your
system. In fact, your unit tests cover all supported uses of your code
(over time). If your code is easy to test, it will also be easy for
clients to use (program against).

If code is difficult to test, you probably have something to learn
about that code's design.

*********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********

On 2002-05-01 at 15:48 Morris, Chris wrote:

>> (It is 'against the rules' to change the design of them to return
>> values - a testing tool should not force code changes.)
>
>What's wrong with forcing production code to change only to make it
more
>testable? I came into the JUnit-ish lifestyle with this belief, but I
don't
>hold to it anymore. Testability is a good quality to have -- and many
times
>it accidently improves the design.
>
>Chris
